title-group.article-title: Fatty acids, tocopherols, selenium and total carotene of pistachios (P. vera L.) from Diyarbakır (Southestern Turkey) and walnuts (J. regia L.) from Erzincan (Eastern Turkey)

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Horticulture, Faculty of Agriculture, Yüzüncü Yıl University, Turkey
2Department of Food Engineering, Faculty of Engineering and Architecture, Yüzüncü Yıl University, Turkey
3Department of Horticulture, Faculty of Agriculture, Ordu University, Turkey

author-notes.corresp: K. Özrenk, Department of Horticulture, Faculty of Agriculture, Yüzüncü Yıl University, Turkey Email: korayozrenk@hotmail.com

abstract.p: In this study, 14 well-adapted genotypes of pistachio (Pistachio vera L.) grown in Diyarbakır (Southeastern Turkey) and 15 walnut (Juglans regia L.) genotypes grown in Erzincan (Eastern Turkey) have been studied. Pistachio genotypes contained 8.16–9.33% palmitic acid, 0.54–0.68% palmitoleic acid, 2.35–4.21% stearic acid, 67.81–76.82% oleic acid, 9.42–18:32% linoleic acid, 0.27–0.38% linolenic acid and 0.19–0.33 % arachidic acid. The range of selenium, α-tocopherol, γ-tocopherol, δ-tocopherol, α-tocotrienoid, γ-tocotrienoid and total carotenoid of these promising genotypes were found to be between 11.44 and 190.71 ng/g, 1.36 and 26.93, 36.17 and 170, 0.45 and 2.61, 0.96 and 3.76, 2.33 and 37.72 and 1.01 and 4.93 mg/kg, respectively. Linoleic acid ranging from 43.19% to 53.16% was the most abundant fatty acid in 15 pomologically selected walnut genotypes, followed by oleic and linolenic acids (31.91% and 11.46%, respectively). Their selenium contents ranged between 7.25 and 57.67 ng/g. γ-Tocopherol was the predominant tocopherol in walnut genotypes. Pistachio and walnut genotypes with higher unsaturated fatty acids, tocopherols and selenium contents may be valuable for nutritional breeding efforts.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Turkey is among the leading countries in pistachio and walnut production in the world. According to the agricultural statistics data (FAO, 2008), Turkey is in the third rank both in pistachio production (120,113 tons) after Iran and USA, and in walnut production (170,897 tons) after China and USA (FAO, 2008). In the last decade, Turkey's pistachio production considerably increased from 35,000 tons (FAO, 2002) to 120,113 tons (FAO, 2008). This increase in production has encouraged researchers to determine the composition of promising genotypes grown in different regions of Turkey to offer opportunities for further genetic improvement of pistachio and walnut quality (Dogan et al., 2010; Demirel et al., 2008; Seferoglu et al., 2006). The pistachio and walnut kernels are often eaten whole either fresh or roasted and salted and are also used in confections, pastry, bakery goods and ice cream. Pistachio and walnut are rich sources of fat and they contain fatty acids which are essential for human diet. Pistachio nuts contain unsaturated fatty acids such as oleic, linoleic and linolenic acid which are important for human nutrition. Oleic acid (71.90%) is the main monounsaturated fatty acid whereas linoleic acid (14.91%) is found to be the dominant polyunsaturated fatty acid (PUFA) in pistachio. The total saturated fatty acids content of pistachio is as low as 11.07% (Dogan et al., 2010). Clinical and epidemiological studies have reported the beneficial effects of pistachio nuts on serum lipids. A diet consisiting of 15% calories as pistachio nuts (about 2–3 ounces per day) over a 4-week period can favorably improve serum lipid profiles in subjects with moderate hypercholesterolemia and may reduce risk of coronary disease (Sheridan et al., 2007). Linoleic acid is the major fatty acid of walnut oil followed by oleic, linolenic, palmitic and stearic acids (Dogan et al., 2010). PUFAs, and particularly omega-3 fatty acids, have been suggested to reduce the risk of heart disease by decreasing total and low-density lipoprotein (LDL)-cholesterol and increasing high-density lipoprotein (HDL)-cholesterol (Davis et al., 2007; Tapsell et al., 2004) and also considered to be effective against rheumatoid arthritis, autoimmune disease and cancer (Abbey et al., 1994). Isocaloric replacement of about 5% energy from saturate fatty acids by oleic acid (or PUFA) has been estimated to reduce coronary heart disease risk by 20–40%, mainly via low LDL-cholesterol reduction. Pistachio and walnut are also good sources for several essential components such as selenium, tocopherols and carotenoids. Selenium is recognised as having anticarcinogenic and antiviral properties and is known to have important roles in reproductive function and development, immunocompetence and ageing (Surai, 2002). Intake of 50 µg/d is considered to represent deficiency, while the safe range for selenium intake is 50-400 µg/d for adults. Tocopherols and tocotrienols are fat-soluble antioxidants that have vitamin E activitiy. Vitamin E acts as an important antioxidant against oxidative modification of LDL, which is accepted as an initial event in the pathogenesis of atherosclerosis (Noguchi and Niki, 1998). Vitamin E is mainly made up of four tocopherols (α-, β-, γ- and δ-) and four tocotrienols (α-, β-, γ- and δ-). Carotenoids are compounds that can act as antioxidants, and in humans β-carotene is a precursor of vitamin A, a pigment essential to vision (Khatib and Vaya, 2010).

This study presents the fatty acid composition and concentration levels of selenium, tocopherols, tocotrienols and total carotene of 14 promising pistachio and 15 promising walnut genotypes grown in Diyarbakır (Southeastern Turkey) and Erzincan regions (Eastern Turkey), respectively.

sec.title: Plant materials
sec.p: The materials of this research were kernels of 14 pistachio genotypes (Pistacia vera L.) from Diyarbakır (Southeastern Turkey) and 15 walnut genotypes from Erzincan (Eastern Turkey). After harvesting from local orchards, ∼2 kg pistachio and walnut samples (three replicates for each variety) were immediately transported to the laboratory and air-dried. The samples were stored in the shell, packed in polyethylene bags and frozen to −30 °C, until the analysis.

sec.title: Fatty acid methyl esters
sec.p: Fat contents (ether-extractable) of samples were extracted according to standard AOAC (1990) procedure. For the preparation of the fatty acid methyl esters (FAMEs) 0.4 g oil were dissolved in 4 mL of isooctane and methylated in 0.2 mL 2 M methanolic KOH. Analysis of FAME was performed on an Agilent 6890 series gas-chromatography equipped with flame-ionization detector and a 60 -m capillary column (ID = 0.25 mm) coated with 0.25 µm of 50%-cyanopropyl-methylpolysiloxane (J&W Scientific, Folsom, CA, USA). Helium was used as a carrier gas at a flow rate of 1.5 mL/min and a split ratio of 1:10. Injector temperature was 250 °C, detector temperature was 260 °C and the oven temperature was programmed at 120 °C for a hold of 5 min and increased to 240 °C at a rate of 15 °C/min and hold at the final temparture for 20 min (Kirazci and Javidipour, 2008). FAMEs were identified by comparison of their retention time and equivalent chain length with respect to standard FAMEs (Supelco, 47885-U). FAMEs in samples were quantified according to their percentage area. All the samples were analyzed in triplicate.

sec.title: Tocopherols, tocotrienols and total carotene
sec.p: The tocopherol and tocotrienol profiles of the samples were determined as described previously by Surai et al. (1996). In brief, 0.5 g of sample was saponified with ethanolic KOH in the presence of pyrogallol and the tocopherols, tocotrienols and carotenoids were extracted from the mixture with hexane (5 mL). The extraction was repeated twice more with 5 mL hexane. Hexane extracts were combined, evaporated and re-dissolved in a mixture of methanol/dichloromethane (1:1, v/v). The extract was dried under nitrogen, redissolved in methanol and injected onto a Spherisorb S30DS2, 3 µm C18 reverse phase HPLC column, 15 cm × 4.6 mm (Phase Separations, Clwyd, UK).

Chromatography was performed using a mobile phase of methanol/water (97:3, v/v) at a flow rate of 1.1 mL/min. Fluorescence detection utilised excitation and emission wavelengths of 295 and 330 nm, respectively. Calibration was performed using standard solutions of tocopherols (Sigma, Poole, UK) and tocotrienols (Merck, Darmstadt, Germany). Total carotene was determined from the same extract using the same HPLC system but fitted with a Spherisorb type S5NH2, 5 µm C18 reverse phase HPLC column, 25 cm × 4.6 mm (Phase Separations, Clwyd, UK). Chromatography was performed using a mobile phase of methanol/water (97:3 v/v) at a flow rate of 1.5 mL/min. Total carotene was identified as a single peak at 445 nm and concentrations were calculated in relation to a lutein standard (Sigma-Aldrich, Poole, UK) (Karadas et al., 2005).

sec.title: Selenium
sec.p: Selenium concentration was determined as previously described (Harsley et al., 1988). This technique utilised hydride generation atomic fluorescence spectroscopy of nitric acid/perchloric acid/water/sulfuric acid (50/25/17.4/7.6 by volume) digested samples. Selenium in the subsequent residue was dissolved in 5 mL HCL (6 mol/L) and heated at 120°C for 30 min. Hydride generation utilized solutions of NaBH4 (0.32 mol/L)/NaOH (1 mol/L) and HCl (3 mol/L) at flow rates of 3.8 and 8 mL/min, respectively. The HCl solution, the sample, and the NaBH4 solution were pumped through a pump head and mixed together in a solenoid valve. The boosted discharge hollow cathode lamp (Superlamp Se, Photon PTY Ltd., Australia) was set at 25 mA and wavelength 196 nm as the excitation source. Atomic fluorescence was measured by a detector (Model 10.033, PS Analytical Ltd., Kent, UK) and the output recorded using Avalon™ Software (PS Analytical Ltd., Kent, UK). Concentrations in the samples were calculated from the linear relationship (r2 = 0.999) obtained using Spectrosol® Selenium Standard Solution (BDH, Poole, UK).

sec.title: Tocopherols and tocotrienols
sec.p:
The pistachio genotypes examined in this study contained 1.36–26.93 mg/kg α-tocopherol, 36.17–170 mg/kg γ-tocopherol, 0.45–2.61 mg/kg δ-tocopherol, 0.96–3.76 mg/kg α-tocotrienol, 2.33–37.72 mg/kg and γ-tocotrienol per kg wet pistachio. γ-Tocopherol was the most abundant tocopherol in the pistachio (Table 3). The α-tocopherol content for dried pistachio reported by Khatib and Vaya (2010) was 1.9 mg/100 g. The total concentration of β- and γ-tocopherols reported by Kornsteiner et al. (2006) for pistachio ranged from 10 to 43.4 mg/100 g oil, with 0.5 mg/100 g oil mean value for δ-tocopherol. Belitz et al. (2004) noted that the α- and γ- tocopherol contents of unripe, ripe and dried ripe kernels of Pistachia vera were 0.7, 0.6, 0.4 and 16.2, 12.9, 8.0 mg/100 g dry matter, respectively. γ-Tocopherol was also the predominant tocopherol in walnut (101.18 ± 9.55 mg/kg; Table 4). It ranged from 32.8 mg/kg (EW42) to 146.43 mg/kg (EW6). Walnut showed lower α-tocopherol (3.98 ± 0.36 mg/kg) but higher δ-tocopherol (6.89 ± 0.14 mg/kg) than pistachio. Pistachio gave considerable amounts of α- and γ-tocotrienols. Tocotrienols were not detected in walnut samples tested in this study. Kornsteiner et al. (2006) noted that walnut contains totally 21.9 mg/100g oil β- and γ-tocopherols and 3.8 mg/100 g oil δ-tocopherol (mean values). The sum of tocopherols for walnut and pistachio oils reported by Arranz et al. (2008) were 249 and 530 mg/kg, respectively. Lavedrine et al. (1997) reported that the total tocopherols (α-. γ- and δ-) of Franquette and Hartley walnut varieties grown in France were 29.62 and 34.74 mg/100 g and for those grown in USA were 26.70 and 28.37 mg/100 g, respectively. They did not detect β-tocopferol in walnut cultivars. Savage et al. (1999) reported the α-, β-, γ- and δ-tocopherol contents of walnut cultivars grown in Lincoln, Canterbury and New Zealand ranged between 18.1 and 28.7, 1.0 and 8.2, 206.9 and 355.0 and 28.0 and 62.1 µg/g oil, respectively. They indiacted that β-tocopferol was present at low levels in walnut oil and previous studies were unable to separate β- and γ-tocopherols. Speak et al. (1999) noted that in some HPLC systems, β- and γ-tocopherols migrated as a single peak. α-Tocopherol is assumed to be the most active form in humans, however γ-tocopherol is reported to be the most prevalent form of vitamin E in plant seeds, especially in nuts (Jiang et al., 2001; Wagner et al., 2004). Nuts such as pistachio and walnut are good dietary sources of α-, β- and γ-tocopherols and can contribute to a balanced intake of vitamin E (Kornsteiner et al., 2006). One of the most developed theory for the cardioprotective effect appears to be concerning tocopherol-induced inhibition of LDL oxidation, which is proposed to play a key role in the atherosclerosis process (Elmadfa and Wagner, 2003). sec.title: Total carotenes
sec.p: The total carotenes concentrations of examined pistachio and walnut cultivars varied between 1.01 and 4.93 mg/kg and 0.08 and 0.49 mg/kg, respectively. Pistachio kernels showed considerable higher amount of carotene than walnut kernels. Bellomo and Fallico (2007) indicated that lutein was the main carotenoid found in pistachio kernels, ranging from 18 to 52 mg/kg dry matter and a β-carotene level <1.8 mg/kg. Kornsteiner et al. (2006) reported that the β-carotene and lutein contents of pistachio varied between non-detectable and 1.0 and 1.5 to 9.6 mg/100 extracted oil, respectively. They mentioned that β-carotene and lutein were not identified in walnut. Carotenoid pigments of plants were reported to have been affected by environmental conditions (Strzalka et al., 2003) and different genotypes (Bang, 2005). Therefore, variations in carotenoid contents can be attributed to plant genetic materials from different geographic origins.

sec.title: Selenium
sec.p: Concentration of selenium determined in the pistachio samples varied in a wide range from 11.44 to 190.71 ng/g, with a mean value of 54.57 ng/g (Table 3). Walnut genotypes showed lower selenium content varied in a narrow range from 7.25 to 57.67 ng/g (Table 4). The quantity of selenium in nut meat may be dependent on whether the nut tree is grown in seleniferous or non-seleniferous soils (Parekh et al., 2008). The selenium concentration of pistachio and walnut grown in Turkey were 0.103 µg/g and 0.028 µg/g, respectively (Demirel et al. 2008). Pappa et al. (2006) reported that selenium concentrations of the pistachio, walnut and almond were found to be 32.7 ± 7.6, 19.2 ± 2.2 and 7.0 ± 1.7 ng/g wet weight, respectively. The selenium content of dry roasted pistachio noted by Khatib and Vaya (2010) was 9.3 µg/100 g. Lavedrine et al. (2000) noted that the selenium content of Franquette and Hartley walnut cultivars grown in France and USA varied between 0.7 and 1.1 µg/100 g, respectively.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Pistachio and walnut are rich sources of some nutritionally important compounds such as essential fatty acids and tocopherols. While pistachio has a high content of oleic acid followed by linoleic acid, walnut is rich in linoleic acid and has a considerable amount of linolenic acid. γ-Tocopherol is the predominant tocopherol in both pistachio and walnut kernels. Pistachio genotypes had higher content of α-tocopherol, but lower δ-tocopherol content than walnut, and also contained noticeable amount of α- and γ-tocotrienols. Pistachio showed higher total carotene and selenium contents than walnut. Higher selenium level in some pistachio and walnut genotypes can be probably attributed to the soil structures, and climate and ecological conditions of the regions. Pistachio and walnut genotypes with superior pomological properties and composition may be valuable for future nutritional breeding efforts.
